confirm what is happening with this.

NHBC asked to have them removed (at the side of the house to the drive). I

that your build manager said he used to check this. The brickwork is not
within NHBC tolerances, and our contract quite clearly states that anything
not to NHBC tolerance will be rectified.

also a copy of the communication from the NHBC confirming that it is within
tolerance and does not need to be touched.

Many thanks

Subject: Fwd: 25 Abbots Road - brickwork confirmation
From: Paul Taylor <paulroberttaylor@gmail.com>
To: Adrian.Sims@crestnicholson.com
Date: Mon, 26 Sep 2022 13:35:07 +0100
Good afternoon,

I will deal with the email and spreadsheet from Friday in a separate email.

*"Crest will be undertaking the works as required to the external brickwork
deviations highlighted in the Calford Seaden report on both the House and
the Garage."*

Calfordseadon's report covers the following issues:

- all perp drift
- all bowing and out of plumb walls
- all missing masonry
- all badly done mortar beds
- all missing weep vents
- all cracked and chipped bricks
- all out of plumb or unlevel bricks
- all badly done sill mortar
- any other brick wall related NHBC standards that have not been met

Please confirm these are the works you are referring to and confirm that
the brickwork will be left in a condition it should have been when brand
new.

Many thanks

From: Paul Taylor <paulroberttaylor@gmail.com>
Date: Thu, 15 Sept 2022, 11:49 am
Subject: 25 Abbots Road - brickwork confirmation
To: <PETER.TRUSCOTT@crestnicholson.com>, <Adrian.Sims@crestnicholson.com>

Please could I have confirmation that all unevenness, cracks, chips, out of
plumb walls, inconsistent thickness of mortar beds, and missing masonry on

I would be grateful if you could contact the relevant manager in your
technical department to answer the question I was assured I would receive
by Donna Hack several weeks ago.

The DPC at the front of the garage is not to NHBC standards, the NHBC has
not visited to check it therefore have not signed it off. The DPC work done
at the rear of the property before exchange was because of the same
technical standard for DPC, and needs to be applied equally everywhere.

Please see clause 1.16.6 in the legal contract prepared by Crest and signed
by both ourselves and Crest:

1.16.6: Any damage or defects which fall within NHBC tolerances.

Therefore, any items reported to you which are not within NHBC tolerances
must be rectified.  The DPC I have reported multiple times is not within
NHBC tolerances.


Mr Taylor

Subject: Final Response Required - Inadequate Damp-Proof Course (DPC) at 10
 Colt View, Bishops Waltham, Southampton, Hampshire, SO32 1TF
From: Paul Taylor <paulroberttaylor@gmail.com>
To: Eileen Guihen <Eileen.Guihen@crestnicholson.com>
Date: Tue, 12 Mar 2024 09:53:46 +0000
Dear Ms Guihen,

I am writing to formally request a final response concerning the inadequate
damp-proof course (DPC) at my family's property, 10 Colt View, Bishops
Waltham, Hampshire, SO32 1TF. I am requesting this final response so that
the NHBC can officially become involved in resolving this matter. The NHBC
has instructed me to seek a final response from you before they can proceed
with their involvement.

The issue of the inadequate DPC was previously brought to your attention
previously. The DPC located at the brick wall between garage doors does not
meet the NHBC minimum tolerances as required by the NHBC Buildmark policy
and Technical Requirements.

Moreover, I would like to draw your attention to a specific clause in the
property contract provided by Crest Nicholson South. This clause, which was
included by your company, explicitly states that any tolerances that are
not met must be addressed as a contractual obligation. I would be grateful
if you could also explain why you are choosing to breach this clause.

In previous correspondence, you stated that you have documentation
verifying that there is no issue with the DPC. As this documentation is
crucial to resolving this matter, I formally request that you provide a
copy of this documentation within the next 7 days. If you are unable to
provide this documentation, please confirm in writing that no such
documentation exists. This confirmation should be included in your final
response.

In light of both the NHBC requirements and your own contractual commitment,
I kindly request that you provide me with a clear outline of your
intentions to rectify this problem, including a reasonable timeframe for
the necessary repairs, to bring the DPC up to the required standards.

I request that you provide me with a final decision letter addressing the
inadequate DPC issue within 30 days of receiving this letter.

Please note that this letter specifically addresses the DPC tolerance
i

From: Paul Taylor <paulroberttaylor@gmail.com>
To: Serhan Handani <sh@bramsdonandchilds.com>
Date: Thu, 11 Jan 2024 10:11:19 +0000
Good morning Serhan,

Crest was supposed to provide a final certification from the surveyor after
they did the remedial works based on the surveyor's visit on the 11th
October. They are however not going to provide it. Their logic is that we
wanted to exchange and complete as soon as possible, which has no relevance
to the certification, but is somehow being used to justify ignoring the
legal contract.

They also claim that the work was done according to the satisfaction of the
surveyor but can't prove it, since the final certification was never given.

It was a requirement as part of the contract for 10 Colt View, and I do not
understand why they feel they can pick and choose what they will abide by
and what they will not.

They are also, despite it being listed in the reservation agreement,
refusing to put a second instance of incorrect DPC right, claiming that the
NHBC standards are only guidelines.  A guideline does not state a minimum
measurement for tolerances.  DPC tolerances are a part of the NHBC's
technical standards.


*Contract for 10 Colt View*

1.14.2. The Seller has undertaken these works (if any) and, if appropriate,
> the surveyor has certified that these works (if any) have been
> satisfactorily completed.

1.16.6. Any damage or defects which fall within NHBC tolerances.


*Reservation Agreement:*

19. Key principles surrounding the structural survey by Trinity Rose:
> a. Following exchange of contracts and prior to completion of the Property
> the Seller and Buyer will jointly instruct Trinity Rose (or other agreed
> accredited RICS surveyor) to undertake a structural
> survey of the Property (paid for by the Seller) in order to identify *any non-compliance
> with NHBC technical standards* or Building Regulations.
> e. The *surveyor will certify once all the required works have been
> satisfactorily completed*. The sale will then proceed to completion.


I have been asking for the surveyor's certificate

From: Paul Taylor <paulroberttaylor@gmail.com>
To: Eileen Guihen <Eileen.Guihen@crestnicholson.com>
Date: Wed, 24 Jan 2024 10:56:10 +0000
Ms Guihen.

I would be grateful if you could contact the relevant manager in your
technical department to answer the question I was assured I would receive
by Donna Hack several weeks ago.

The DPC at the front of the garage is not to NHBC standards, the NHBC has
not visited to check it therefore have not signed it off. The DPC work done
at the rear of the property before exchange was because of the same
technical standard for DPC, and needs to be applied equally everywhere.

Please see clause 1.16.6 in the legal contract prepared by Crest and signed
by both ourselves and Crest:

1.16.6: Any damage or defects which fall within NHBC tolerances.

Therefore, any items reported to you which are not within NHBC tolerances
must be rectified.  The DPC I have reported multiple times is not within
NHBC tolerances.


Mr Taylor

Subject: Re: 34 AW complaint pathway to resolution for 05010240-34AW
From: Paul Taylor <paulroberttaylor@gmail.com>
To: Serhan Handani <sh@bramsdonandchilds.com>
Date: Thu, 11 Jan 2024 10:11:19 +0000
Good morning Serhan,

Crest was supposed to provide a final certification from the surveyor after
they did the remedial works based on the surveyor's visit on the 11th
October. They are however not going to provide it. Their logic is that we
wanted to exchange and complete as soon as possible, which has no relevance
to the certification, but is somehow being used to justify ignoring the
legal contract.

They also claim that the work was done according to the satisfaction of the
surveyor but can't prove it, since the final certification was never given.

It was a requirement as part of the contract for 10 Colt View, and I do not
understand why they feel they can pick and choose what they will abide by
and what they will not.

They are also, despite it being listed in the reservation agreement,
refusing to put a second instance of incorrect DPC right, claiming that the
NHBC standards are only guidelines.  A guideline does not state a minimum
measurement for tolerances.  DPC tolerances are a part of the NHBC's
technical standards.


*Contract for 10 Colt View*

1.14.2. The Seller has undertaken these works (if any) and, if appropriate,
> the surveyor has certified that these works (if any) have been
> satisfactorily completed.

1.16.6. Any damage or defects which fall within NHBC tolerances.


*Reservation Agreement:*

19. Key principles surrounding the structural survey by Trinity Rose:
> a. Following exchange of contracts and prior to completion of the Property
> the Seller and Buyer will jointly instruct Trinity Rose (or other agreed
> accredited RICS surveyor) to undertake a structural
> survey of the Property (paid for by the Seller) in order to identify *any non-compliance
> with NHBC technical standards* or Building Regulations.
> e. The *surveyor will certify once all the required works have been
> satisfactorily completed*. The sale will then proceed to completion.


I have been asking for the surveyor's certificate

 Colt View, Bishops Waltham, Southampton, Hampshire, SO32 1TF

Dear Ms Guihen,

I am writing to formally request a final response concerning the inadequate
damp-proof course (DPC) at my family's property, 10 Colt View, Bishops
Waltham, Hampshire, SO32 1TF. I am requesting this final response so that
the NHBC can officially become involved in resolving this matter. The NHBC
has instructed me to seek a final response from you before they can proceed
with their involvement.

The issue of the inadequate DPC was previously brought to your attention
previously. The DPC located at the brick wall between garage doors does not
meet the NHBC minimum tolerances as required by the NHBC Buildmark policy
and Technical Requirements.

Moreover, I would like to draw your attention to a specific clause in the
property contract provided by Crest Nicholson South. This clause, which was
included by your company, explicitly states that any tolerances that are
not met must be addressed as a contractual obligation. I would be grateful
if you could also explain why you are choosing to breach this clause.

In previous correspondence, you stated that you have documentation
verifying that there is no issue with the DPC. As this documentation is
crucial to resolving this matter, I formally request that you provide a
copy of this documentation within the next 7 days. If you are unable to
provide this documentation, please confirm in writing that no such
documentation exists. This confirmation should be included in your final
response.

In light of both the NHBC requirements and your own contractual commitment,
I kindly request that you provide me with a clear outline of your
intentions to rectify this problem, including a reasonable timeframe for
the necessary repairs, to bring the DPC up to the required standards.

I request that you provide me with a final decision letter addressing the
inadequate DPC issue within 30 days of receiving this letter.

Please note that this letter specifically addresses the DPC tolerance

Subject: RE: Access to Bridal Path - Crest Nicholson
From: Sharnie Evans <sharnie.evans@nhos.org.uk>
To: "paulroberttaylor@gmail.com" <paulroberttaylor@gmail.com>
Date: Thu, 17 Oct 2024 15:24:41 +0000
Good afternoon Paul,

Thank you for your email.

If the bridal path access forms a requirement under the S106 agreement then there would be an obligation as part of their planning consent to fulfil this. It would form part of a condition for their planning permission that they would need formally discharge (i.e: prove they have implemented it) with the local planning authority. The exact legalities of this we would not be able to advise upon, however, as we are not a legal advice service. You would need to run this past an independent legal advisor for further information.

Unless you have formally raised this as a complaint with the developer and completed their complaints process it is also not something we would be able to consider with an ongoing complaint. You would either need to put this on hold until you meet our eligibility requirements; or you would need to raise this as a separate complaint at a later date.

I trust this clarifies matters for you and would recommend, as above, seeking some legal advice.


Kind regards,


Sharnie Evans
Caseworker | New Homes Ombudsman Service | www.nhos.org.uk<http://www.nhos.org.uk/>
E:  sharnie.evans@nhos.org.uk<mailto:sharnie.evans@nhos.org.uk>
Main number: 0330 808 4286
